variant.question:

Forecast Wind: 020°/20 kt,   
 Average Approach TAS: 130 kt,   
 Variation in the vicinity of the destination aerodrome: 4°W.

A flight has been diverted off the planned route due to the bad weather. ATC clears the flight to re-join the planned route at TUSKA. The pilot wishes to decide early, if there is enough fuel to safely complete the flight or if a fuel diversion is needed, so he/she checks the fuel at 18:06 UTC. Following the data, what is minimum fuel required at 18:06 UTC to complete the planned flight?

Average fuel flow: 45 kg/h   
ETO TUSKA: 18:43 UTC

Alternate fuel, including final reserve fuel: 17 US gallons   
Contingency fuel: 5% of trip fuel   
Usable fuel at departure: 93 US gallons

options.text: The remaining fuel is not sufficient to reach the destination with reserves intact.
At departure the reserve fuel was 28 US gallons.
At the destination there will still be 30 US gallons in the tanks.
At the destination the required reserves remain intact.

variant.question: During a navigation flight, the pilot makes in-flight checks to monitor the progress of the flight. During the last leg, he/she notices that the planned timings overhead the chosen waypoints are NOT corresponding to the actual timings, and that the aircraft is getting behind the timings. Both the planned and actual airspeed are 160 kt. What is the main reason for the deviation from the planned timings?

options.text: The actual wind (direction or speed) is different to the forecast wind.
The increase in aerodynamic drag resulting in a slower groundspeed.
The actual fuel consumption is different to the planned consumption.
The actual groundspeed is faster than that calculated during the planning phase.

An aeroplane is performing a commercial air transport flight. Regular fuel checks performed approximately every 30 min as required by the operator. The flight follows the planned route and the flies at the mach number as planned. The fuel measurements are accurate within +/- 20 kg and the fuel flow indicators show a constant 1340 kg/h per engine throughout.

What is the reason for the creation of the position of PBD05 + 10 min?

options.text: The aeroplane has less fuel than required but the fuel flow is verified as correct enabling a reasonable conclusion that any discrepancy is due to the wind being different to planned.
The fuel flow appear to be gradually increasing and one way of verifying this is to create a waypoint based on time and use the last known fuel depletion rate to assess any trends.
The fuel flow is confirmed to be different from the plan and therefore the fuel flow indicators are showing incorrect and the thrust can be reduced to match the planned fuel flow.
The fuel flow appear to be gradually reducing and in order to verify a revised fuel flow of 2850 kg/h the new waypoint enables this and a revised landing fuel may be calculated.

variant.question:
Given the following information for a Commercial Air Transport flight, what action should be taken by the Commander?

Take-Off Fuel: 3300 lb   
Trip Fuel: 1800 lb   
Alternate 1 Fuel: 800 lb   
Alternate 2 Fuel: 500 lb   
Final Reserve Fuel: 600 lb   
Total Distance to Destination: 800 NM   
Remaining Fuel after 400 NM: 2300 lb

options.text: the remaining fuel at Alternate 1 will be more than the Final Reserve Fuel.
Continue the flight; in case of diversion proceed to Alternate 2
Declare an emergency as the remaining fuel is less than the Final Reserve Fuel at Alternate 1.
Continue the flight; the remaining fuel at Alternate 1 will be more than the Final Reserve Fuel.

Which statement is correct regarding the altimeter temperature error correction during a final approach to an aerodrome?

options.text: Temperature error correction should be applied when the aerodrome temperature is ISA and below and added only to the DH/DA and MDH/MDA.
Temperature error correction should be applied when the aerodrome temperature is much lower than ISA and subtracted from the DH/DA or MDH/MDA and step-down fixes inside the FAF.
Temperature error correction should be applied when the aerodrome temperature is ISA and below and subtracted only from the DH/DA or MDH/MDA.
Temperature error correction should be applied when the aerodrome temperature is much lower than ISA and added to the DH/DA or MDH/MDA and step-down fixes inside the FAF.

A flight crew is operating a Commercial Air Transport flight and arriving in VMC overhead the holding fix on the approach towards the destination airport A when ATC tells the Commander to take up the hold and expect 17 minutes delay. Use the data below for available fuel on board when commencing the hold and find the LEGAL and preferred COMMERCIAL solution.

Alternate Fuel: 40 minutes.   
 Final Reserve Fuel: 30 minutes.   
 Extra Fuel: 10 minutes.

options.text: Immediately divert to the destination alternate since there is NOT sufficient fuel to hold for the estimated 17 minutes, thereby having extra fuel when landing at the destination alternate.
Hold for 17 minutes, and after that time if landing isn't possible, proceed to alternate using the alternate fuel remaining.
Hold 10 minutes to see effectively if it's a 17 minutes holding, and in case it is, proceed to the alternate, leaving the 30 minutes of final reserve fuel intact.
Declare minimum fuel to ATC as that will guarantee priority and ATC will ensure that the aeroplane will only hold for the available time to land with alternate fuel plus final reserve fuel.

variant.question:
Refer to figure.   
During the very early stages of flight, the trim tank pump becomes inoperative and there is no possibility to override it manually. Given the following data, the fuel available for the remainder of the flight is:

Trim tank: Full   
Outer tanks: Full   
Inner tanks: 15 000 kg each

According to below find the fuel remaining in Liters:

| |  ETO | ATO   | Planned Fuel (L) | Actual Fuel (L) |     |
| ------ | ----- | ---------------- | --------------- | --- |
| 1      | 10:02 | 10:00            | 133             | 137 |
| 2      | 10:10 | 10:08            | 126             | 130 |
| 3      | 10:32 |                  |                 |     |

If the Fuel flow is 52 l/h :

Refer to figure.

The annex depicts a pilot's flight plan/log from LPFR to LEMG extracted by a flight planning software. When approaching VJF, the pilots realizes abnormal airframe vibrations and reduces speed from VJF. When overhead Tarifa, the pilot calculates that according to the new speed, the flight time from Tarifa to LEMG will be 47 minutes. Taking into account the latest fuel flow after VJF, the fuel consumption will be...

options.text: lower since the fuel flow has reduced to 141 kg/h giving 120 kg fuel remaining when landing in LEMG.
greater since the effect of the reduced fuel flow is offset by the lower speed giving 24 kg less fuel than planned in LEMG.
lower since the lower speed gives a lower fuel flow which results in landing with 24 kg more fuel than planned in LEMG.
greater since the fuel flow has increased to 163 kg/h giving 120 kg fuel remaining when landing in LEMG.

variant.question: Due to a passenger's serious illness while en-route, the aircraft must divert to the nearest suitable airfield. The FMC calculates a flight time of 26 minutes to the nearest diversion airfield and shows a gross mass of 78 200 kg. The fuel on board is 9 200 kg and the FMC gives a fuel on landing of 8 700 kg. How much is the landing mass?

For a planned flight the calculated fuel is as listed below. How much fuel should be aboard to cover the rest of the flight, if the remaining flight time to destination is 1 hour 45 minutes?

Trip Fuel: sufficient for a planned flight time of 4 hours 45 minutes   
Operator’s specified Reserve Fuel: 30% of the planned Trip Fuel   
Start up and Taxi Fuel: 35 kg   
Block Fuel: 890 kg

In order to follow the planned track, a pilot flies a True Heading of 040º, which was calculated for the forecast wind of 160°/40kt. The actual wind encountered at his/her altitude is 100°/40kt.

What will the in-flight track be?

options.text: There is not enough information to answer this question.

variant.question:
Refer to figure.

Given: Planned and actual data as shown in the Flight Log excerpt. Arriving overhead GAMMA you are cleared for direct routeing to MIKE. The flight time for direct flight GAMMA to MIKE will be 40 min.

Provided that flight conditions on the direct leg GAMMA to MIKE remain unchanged and fuel consumption remains unchanged, what fuel remaining should be expected at waypoint MIKE?
